author: @suivzmoi
text: probability is the quantity most people are familiar with which deals with predicting new data given a known model ("what is the probability of getting heads six times in a row flipping this 50:50 coin?") while likelihood deals with fitting models given some known data ("what is the likelihood that this coin is/isn't rigged given that I just flipped heads six times in a row?"). I wanted to add this perspective because using the example in this clip, a likelihood quantity such as 0.12 is not meaningful to the layman unless it is explained exactly what 0.12 means: a measure of the sample's support for the assumed model i.e. low values either mean rare data or incorrect model!

author: @debayankoley5844
text: I just want to point out one thing, which I've recently realised. The definition and interpretations of likelihood given in this video are confined within the Classical paradigm. Bayesian school also uses likelihood, and although the structure of likelihood is the same, their interpretations of likelihood are different. That‚Äôs largely because in Classical statistics, a parameter (In this case, location and scale of normal distribution) is a fixed quantity whereas data are random. Bayesians consider exactly the opposite. For them, parameters are random and observations are fixed. It can be seen in this way: in Classical statistics, likelihood is the probability that our observed set of data will yield the model parameter(s) whereas in Bayesian statistics, likelihood is the probability that the parameter(s) will generate the data we are observing.

author: @Julian-tf8nj
text: *THE* central point of why this distinction/confusion IS even an issue - ought to be addressed by this video: it's because it's a *CONTINUOUS* distribution! If you had a *DISCRETE* distribution, there'd be no such issue: the probability of a fair die landing on "4" is 1/6.  You can call it probability, likelihood, odds - _whatever you jolly well fancy!_  [insert British accent] But with a CONTINUOUS distribution, like in this video, ask yourself, *"what is the probability of a mouse weighing 32 grams?"* The answer is... drums rolling... (think about it...) ZERO! That's because you're asking about EXACTLY 32 grams, not an atom more or less!!  What are the odds of that, lol.  So, to have a PROBABILITY value that is actually useful in the _continuous_ case, you must specify a broader "event" in your sample space - i.e. a subset of the real numbers in this case, not a single point.  For example, if your scale gives you tenths of grams, and you cared about such minute variation, you could ask about Prob(32.0 <= weight <= 32.1)  LIKELIHOOD, on the other hand, is just the value of the _Probability Density Function_ (often called pdf) - that is the y-value on the curve in this example - at a particular point; if it were a discrete distribution, it'd simply give you the probability at that point (and it'd drop the "density" part from the name of the function.)  _Note that the "likelihood", unlike a probability, can be any number_ - it's NOT constrained to be between 0 and 1.  For example, imagine a rectangular bell-curve analog, always 0 except between 50.0 and 50.1 , where it takes a value of 10.  The total area under that curve is (50.1 - 50.0) * 10. = 1.0 as it should.  So the likelihood in that scenario is always 0, except when it is 10.

author: @Luis-zc8gl
text: What I see is that likelihood is a kind of measure of "what distribution is more likely, given data". In the case of continuous random variables it cannot be the same as probability because pdf are not always restricted to the [0,1] interval (for example, the Chi-square distribution with 1 df). So, the 0.12 in the example shouldn't be interpreted as a "probability". What are the units of measurement of likelihood? It's hard to say. In the case of discrete random variables, likelihood and probability are "the same" but I am not sure if we can interpret the values of the likelihood function as a probability. Finally and curiously, in most applied examples the maximum loglikelihood is usually a negative number, which is consistent with a joint probability restricted to the interval [0,1], and this occurs in the case of discrete and continuous random variables.

text: You are making things sound much more complicated than they actually are. The key concept to understand is the (cumulative) probability distribution. All quantities can then be derived from that, either as differences or as derivatives. That's it! (This has a deeper measure-theoretic meaning, in additivity, and as a Radon-Nikodym derivative, but let's not get into that. The nice thing with this is that you don't need to differentiate between continuous and discrete PDFs. But since you are a mathematician you already know these things.) The term "likelihood" needs to be further specialized. The (log-)likelihood of the parameters, theta, is the function L(theta) = log p(x | theta, "other stuff"). That is, it is the probability of observing a particular instance of "x" under a given model.

author: @magister.mortran
text: In language both words are synonyns.  According to your mathematical definition likelihood is mathematically just a special case of probability, where the weight range is zero, which makes it a meaningless concept in the real world. If you count the number of mice with a certain weight, you always need a weight range. With a weight range of zero there would always be just one mouse with the exact particular weight, so you would never get a distribution curve. In the real world we can only deal with areas under this curve, never with points on the curve. In order to count thr mice with the same weight, we would need a tolerance range for considering mice having the same weight. The distinction between probability and likelihood makes therefore no sense, since likelihood would not be an applicable concept in the real world.

text: 3:20 The likelihood of weighing a 34-gram mouse is 0.12. But, 0.12 _what_? It's not 12 percent. The only units that make sense given that an area (i.e. probability) works out to a fraction is if the units are "0.12 per gram." But that doesn't have any intuitive meaning.  Reading off a likelihood value in isolation like that isn't meaningful. Individual likelihood values are only meaningful when compared to other likelihood values. The 34 gram mouse on this distribution is 0.12, and the 32 gram mouse is 0.21. So we can correctly conclude that the 34 gram mouse is 0.12/0.21 = 57% as likely to occur (i.e. be selected) as the 32 gram mouse.
